channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Pope Francis’ Climate Error
item.description: To control emissions, a carbon market is best.
item.dc:creator: JOSEPH HEATH

item.title: Dominican Deadline Passes Without Mass Expulsion of Haitian Migrants
item.description: The expected mass deportation of Haitian immigrants in the Dominican Republic failed to materialize in the two days after the government’s deadline for them to normalize their status.
item.dc:creator: SANDRA E. GARCIA and AZAM AHMED
item.media:description: Milene Monime, 16, in a classroom in Haiti on Thursday, a day after being deported from the Dominican Republic. Her 2-month-old son slept with another child.

item.title: Genome Studies Show How Ebola Spread Initially
item.description: Scientists have developed a fuller picture of how the virus spread and evolved by tracking mutations in its genome.
item.dc:creator: SHERI FINK

item.title: World Briefing: Mexico: Ex-Governor Charged
item.description: The former governor of the northeast Mexican border state of Tamaulipas has been indicted on money-laundering charges in South Texas, prosecutors said Friday.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: World Briefing: Russia: Election Bill Advances
item.description: Lawmakers in the lower house of Parliament gave tentative approval on Friday to a bill that would move up next year’s parliamentary elections by three months.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: France: Mideast Peace on Agenda
item.description: The French foreign minister will travel to the Middle East for meetings that the government asserts will be an effort to restart peace negotiations between Israel and the Palestinians.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: Unicef Fears Surge in Child Trafficking After Nepal Quakes
item.description: Trafficking in Nepalese children was a problem before two earthquakes struck in April, but Unicef and the government fear the ensuing chaos may make a problem even worse.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Red Tape Untangled, Young Nepalese Monks Find Ride to Safety
item.description: Fifty-nine students, mostly boys, were airlifted by helicopter out of an isolated Buddhist monastery destroyed by the earthquake that struck Nepal in April.
item.dc:creator: DONATELLA LORCH
item.media:credit: Donatella Lorch for The New York Times
item.media:description: A young Buddhist monk on his first helicopter flight, as he and fellow students were airlifted from their isolated monastery.

item.title: Greece and Its Creditors Pummel Each Other, but Fight Is Not Over Yet
item.description: Like prizefighters, the two sides of the negotiations over the Greek bailout have been circling each other, throwing punch after punch.
item.dc:creator: SUZANNE DALEY
item.media:description: Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras of Greece, second from right, during a meeting with Russian officials in St. Petersburg on Friday.

item.title: Russia and Greece Flaunt Solidarity at Business Forum, but Deals Are Scarce
item.description: The economic embrace between President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and the Greek premier, Alexis Tsipras, seemed mostly about thumbing their noses at Europe.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:description: Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras of Greece attends an economic forum in St. Petersburg, Russia, with President Vladimir V. Putin.

item.title: Yemen Mediator Optimistic as Humanitarian Crisis Worsens
item.description: The United Nations mediator for Yemen’s talks with Houthi rebels said discussions yielded no progress, not even for a humanitarian cease-fire.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.media:description: Yemenis waited to buy food and water in Taiz on Friday. The United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, has appealed for a two-week humanitarian truce in honor of Ramadan, which began this week.

item.title: Two Israeli Men Are Attacked, and One Killed, Near Settlement in the West Bank
item.description: The attacker opened fire on a civilian vehicle near a Jewish settlement in the occupied West Bank on Friday, Israel’s military said in a statement.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: India and the Politics of Yoga
item.description: Prime Minister Modi’s goal for International Yoga Day is to promote India’s brand, not the Hindu religion.
item.dc:creator: MANIL SURI

item.title: Rise of Far-Right Party in Denmark Reflects Europe’s Unease
item.description: The anti-immigration Danish People’s Party took second in Thursday’s vote, underlining a growing crisis of confidence in the Continent’s traditional politics.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: Supporters of the Alternative, a newly elected green party, celebrated on Thursday in Copenhagen. Political parties expressing anger and anxiety are gaining traction in the European Union.

item.title: Afghan Parliament’s Term Is Extended After Squabbles Delay Elections
item.description: President Ashraf Ghani lengthened the term of the current Parliament, which was to expire on Sunday, to allow time to negotiate a new date and process for elections.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL
item.media:description: Abdullah Abdullah, left, and Ashraf Ghani in September 2014. Mr. Ghani issued an extension on Friday for the sitting Parliament after he and Mr. Abdullah could not agree on a date and process for new parliamentary elections.

item.title: Iran Still Aids Terrorism and Bolsters Syria’s President, State Department Finds
item.description: The country has been unwilling to moderate its foreign policy in the Middle East or bring Qaeda members to justice, an annual report released on Friday said.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL R. GORDON and ERIC SCHMITT

item.title: A Show Finds Humor in Gaza’s Headlines. Will Hamas Get It?
item.description: A new satirical video series in Gaza pokes fun at Palestinian leaders, and tests boundaries set by the Hamas-led government.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID and MAJD AL WAHEIDI
item.media:credit: Wissam Nassar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mohamed Alsawafiri, the presenter of “The News Program,” playing with a prop on the set last month.

item.title: Brazil Arrests Head of Odebrecht in Petrobras Scandal
item.description: The investigation is looking into whether subcontractors may have colluded with top Petrobras executives to overbill the company and pay bribes.
item.dc:creator: DAN HORCH
item.media:description: Marcelo Odebrecht, the billionaire chief executive of the Odebrecht conglomerate, was implicated in the corruption case.

item.title: Door Opens Slightly to Cuba, but Businesses Face Difficulty Getting In
item.description: For all the early optimism, businesses and advocates for engagement are increasingly finding that genuine normalization is still more aspiration than reality.
item.dc:creator: LIZETTE ALVAREZ
item.media:description: A group of Americans on a guided tour in Old Havana in May 2015.

item.title: In English, French Paper Urges Britain to Heed Waterloo and Stay in E.U.
item.description: In an unusual step, an editorial in Le Monde said Napoleon’s defeat 200 years ago offered a lesson on European unity and its peaceful rewards.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN
